TrimPath. junctionClient

Be aware that the TrimPath.junctionClient object and its methods are only available in client-side, DOM event-handler style of code.  That is, you may only invoke TrimPath.junctionClient methods only in response to a DOM event handler or in a <script> block.

For example, even though your application’s web-MVC code might be downloaded to be executed within a web-browser, your web-MVC code is still classified as ‘server-side’ code.  Thus, ‘server-side’ code is not allowed to access the TrimPath.junctionClient object.  Similarly, ‘server-side’ code is not allowed to access the document, window, or alert() DOM objects and API.

Summary

Functions

get

get : function(controllerName,
actionName,
objId,
req)

Sends a GET request through the Junction system.

If the application (web-MVC code) is executing on the client-side, hosted within the web browser, then the TrimPath.junctionClient.get() method call is handled by the client-side Junction system.  The client-side Junction system will execute an action method on a Controller within the web browser.  The response HTML string is used by the client-side Junction system to replace the current page.

On the other hand, if the application (web-MVC code) is executing on the server-side, within a remote web-application-server, the TrimPath.junctionClient.get() method will simply returns a boolean value of true.  When used as the value of an <A> link onclick event handler, this signals to the web browser to process the link click as normal.  So, the web browser will send a genuine HTTP GET request message to a remote server.  The Junction system running on the remote server will execute an action method on a Controller, and reply with a response HTML message.  The web browser will replace the entire current page with that response HTML.

The example below shows the usual pattern for using TrimPath.junctionClient.get() in an <A> link onclick attribute.  The linkToLocal() method helps to generate such <A> links.

Example

<a href="?controllerName=invoice&actionName=list"
   onclick="return TrimPath.junctionClient.get('invoice', 'list');">
   List All Invoices</a>

// The above could have been generated by calling...
<%= linkToLocal('List All Invoices', 'invoice', 'list') %>

Parameters

  • controllerName - A string name of a Controller in the application.
  • actionName - A string name of an action method of the Controller.
  • objId - An optional value that helps the action method focus its operation.  Or, may be null.
  • req - An optional hash/map object that holds more key/value request parameters.

Returns

  • true, if the application is executing on the server-side.
  • false, if the application is executing on the client-side.  When used in an <A> link onclick event handler, the false return value prevents the web browser from processing the click event as normal, so the web browser will not fire off a true HTTP request.

In either case, though, the current page contents will be replaced with the result of processing the requested controller/action.

getAsync

getAsync : function(controllerName,
actionName,
objId,
req,
callbacks)

Sends an asynchronous GET request to the client-side Junction system.  Unlike with TrimPath.junctionClient.get(), the getAsync() method does not alter the current page.  Instead, it calls a given callback parameter function with the response.

Parameters

  • controllerName - A string name of a Controller in the application.
  • actionName - A string name of an action method of the Controller.
  • objId - An optional value that helps the action method focus its operation.  Or, may be null.
  • req - A optional hash/map object that holds more key/value request parameters.
  • callbacks - An optional hash/map object.

Callbacks

  • onComplete - A function of one argument, the result of the controller/action request.

Returns

void.  If successful, though, the current page contents will be replaced with the result of processing the controller/action in the local, client-side Junction system.

post

post : function(controllerName,
actionName,
objId,
req)

Sends a POST request through the Junction system.

Similar to the TrimPath.junctionClient.get() method, except the HTTP method will be a ‘post’.

Developers should usually favor the more useful TrimPath.junctionClient.postForm() method instead of this lower-level post() method.

Parameters

  • controllerName - A string name of a Controller in the application.
  • actionName - A string name of an action method of the Controller.
  • objId - An optional value that helps the action method focus its operation.  Or, may be null.
  • req - An optional hash/map object that holds more key/value request parameters.

Returns

  • true, if the application is executing on the server-side.
  • false, if the application is executing on the client-side.  When used in an DOM event handler, the false return value prevents the web browser from processing the event as normal, so the web browser will not fire off a true HTTP request.

In either case, though, the current page contents will be replaced with the result of processing the requested controller/action.

postAsync

postAsync : function(controllerName,
actionName,
objId,
req,
callbacks)

Sends a POST request through the Junction system.

Similar to the TrimPath.junctionClient.getAsync() method, except the HTTP method will be a ‘post’.

Parameters

  • controllerName - A string name of a Controller in the application.
  • actionName - A string name of an action method of the Controller.
  • objId - An optional value that helps the action method focus its operation.  Or, may be null.
  • req - An optional hash/map object that holds more key/value request parameters.
  • callbacks - An optional hash/map object.

Callbacks

  • onComplete - A function of one argument, the result of the controller/action request.

Returns

  • true, if the application is executing on the server-side.
  • false, if the application is executing on the client-side.  When used in an DOM event handler, the false return value prevents the web browser from processing the event as normal, so the web browser will not fire off a true HTTP request.

In either case, though, the current page contents will be replaced with the result of processing the requested controller/action.

postForm

postForm : function(formEl,
controllerName,
actionName,
objId,
req,
submitButtonName)

Sends a POST request through the Junction system.

Similar to the TrimPath.junctionClient.get() method, except the HTTP method will be a ‘post’.

If the application (web-MVC code) is executing on the client-side, hosted within the web browser, then the TrimPath.junctionClient.postForm() method call is handled by the client-side Junction system.  The client-side Junction system will execute an action method on a Controller within the web browser.  The response HTML string is used by the client-side Junction system to replace the current page.

On the other hand, if the application (web-MVC code) is executing on the server-side, within a remote web-application-server, the TrimPath.junctionClient.post() method will simply returns a boolean value of true.  When used as the value of an <input type=”submit”> onclick event handler, this signals to the web browser to process the submit button click as normal.  So, the web browser will send a genuine form HTTP POST request message to a remote server.  The Junction system running on the remote server will execute an action method on a Controller, and reply with a response HTML message.  The web browser will replace the entire current page with that response HTML.

The example below shows the usual pattern for using TrimPath.junctionClient.postForm() in an <input type=”submit”> onclick attribute.  The startFormTagLocal() and submitButtonLocal() helper methods are useful to help to generate such HTML.

The following example shows a common pattern of usage...

Example

<form action="?controllerName=order&action=create"
      method="post"
      onsubmit="return TrimPath.junctionClient.postForm(document.getElementById('myForm'), 'order', 'create');"
      id="myForm">
  <!-- ... other <input> controls ... -->
  <input type="submit"
         id="go"
         name="go"
         value="Create Order"
         onclick="return TrimPath.junctionClient.postForm(document.getElementById(...), 'order', 'create');"/>
</form>

// The above HTML could have been generated by calls to the helper functions...

<%= start_form_tag_local('order', 'create', null, { id: 'myForm' }) %>
  <!-- ... other <input> controls ... -->
  <%= submit_button_local('go', 'Create Order') %>
<%= end_form_tag %>

Parameters

  • formEl - A <FORM> DOM element.
  • controllerName - A string name of a Controller in the application.
  • actionName - A string name of an action method of the Controller.
  • objId - An optional value that helps the action method focus its operation.  Or, may be null.
  • req - An optional hash/map object that holds more key/value request parameters.

Returns

  • true, if the application is executing on the server-side.
  • false, if the application is executing on the client-side.  When used in an DOM event handler, the false return value prevents the web browser from processing the event as normal, so the web browser will not fire off a true HTTP request.

In either case, though, the current page contents will be replaced with the result of processing the requested controller/action.

formToReq

formToReq : function(formEl,
submitButtonName,
req)

Fills a req hash/map object with key/values from <input> controls in a <form>.

Parameters

  • formEl - A <FORM> DOM eleemnt.
  • submitButtonName - An optional string name of the <input type=”submit”> button that fired off the request.
  • req - An optional hash/map to fill and return.

Returns

The req hash/map object, or a new hash/map object if req is null.  The returned hash/map will contain keys/values set from the <input> control elements of the formEl.
